title: Universal Music Representations? Evaluating Foundation Models on World Music Corpora
author: Charilaos Papaioannou (National Technical University of Athens), Emmanouil Benetos (Queen Mary University of London), Alexandros Potamianos (National Technical University of Athens), ... , Alexander Potamianos (Archimedes, Athena Research Center)
relevance_why: The paper explores evaluation methodologies that can be applied to music tagging, which could inform Haohe Liu's work in audio generation and processing techniques.
background: This study evaluates how well audio foundation models, typically trained on Western music, can generalize to non-Western world music datasets.
contribution: This paper introduces a comprehensive evaluation framework to assess audio foundation models' cross-cultural capabilities, achieving state-of-the-art results on five out of six datasets.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous models focused mainly on Western music data and their performance in diverse settings was largely unexplored.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work incorporates methods like probing and supervised fine-tuning alongside few-shot learning to examine cultural representation in models.

key_innovation: Pioneers a systematic evaluation of foundation models across diverse musical traditions with optimized few-shot learning techniques.
real_world_impact: This research has potential implications for developing more inclusive music applications that understand global musical styles. It promotes a more equitable approach to music information retrieval.
limitations: While the models show promising results, performance significantly declines for culturally distant traditions, indicating that the models still retain a bias toward Western music.

new_terms.multi-label few-shot learning: **Multi-label few-shot learning** refers to a learning scenario where a model must predict multiple labels for an example with only a few labeled examples for each class.
new_terms.probing: **Probing** is a technique that uses pre-trained models as fixed feature extractors to evaluate the quality of their representations by training a simple classifier on top.
